body: Cool, thanks.  "Busy" is more clear to me than "top".  You could just use "busy" and make the name something like TSERV_LOG_BUSY_TABLETS_COUNT

This supersedes #1112 (it incorporates @jzgithub1 's changes from that issue, but makes further alterations) and should wrap up #1052 completely (or at least enough for 2.0).
This has been superseded by #1188; @jzgithub1 's changes here were incorporated into that PR, before I made further alterations.

It seems like this issue is specific to the GraphiteSink, which can fail to initialize if it can't connect. I don't think this would be an issue with a different sink, perhaps one that receives metrics and asynchronously passes them along.

We could perhaps retry initializing the whole metrics system again if it fails the first time, but initializing in a loop seems wrong to me... especially since the connection could still be lost later, and at any time. If anything is to be done about this, I think it'd be best to contribute improvements to the GraphiteSink, or encourage people to use a different (better) sink.
Haven't seen this recently. It looks like #1082 probably fixed this.

> Many of these fell into the 'null" command prefix bunch
The initial finding for these tests failing was due to the server prefix property not being set to "" in the accumulo-it.properties file.  This caused a "null" prefix on command line commands being executed.  When that was fixed any tests that required that server prefix were working.

Ok, then it seems like just replacing the log statements with RuntimeExceptions in the catch blocks will do what this ticket is looking for.  I will submit a pull request with that solution as a start and see what comments I get.  Thanks.

Also seeing this with the "instance option"
```
Was passed main parameter '-i' but no main parameter was defined in your arg class
```

Try: `shopt -s globstar; grep -R '"-p"' **/src/main/java/`

The output shows ShellIT and ShellServerIT both using `-p`, and those tests pass fine. Perhaps the issue is with your script?

> Try: `shopt -s globstar; grep -R '"-p"' **/src/main/java/`
> 
> The output shows ShellIT and ShellServerIT both using `-p`, and those tests pass fine. Perhaps the issue is with your script?

I think its with ``` TestIngest ``` since that is what the script is using.  Here is what is causing issues:

```
accumulo org.apache.accumulo.test.TestIngest -i uno -u root -p secret --rows "${ROWS}"
```

Checkout ``` shopt -s globstar; grep -R 'TestIngest' **/src/main/java/ ``` We using it in a bunch of Tests but doesn't look like we use it in the Shell tests.

I suspect this is one of those ones that @mikewalch updated to use the client properties file. When I run your grep, I get a bunch that look like they are passing: `["-c", getClientPropsPath()]`, with the expectation that the password and instance information is in the client props file.

> ...if object already has Closable or analog of close implementation like MetaDataTableScanner it is looks simple to rely just on close call.

Yes, but we'd need to ensure callers are calling the `close()` method in a try-with-resources block or in a finally block.

Other options might be to use Java's new Cleaner utility (with PhantomReferences?), whose API I'm not yet familiar with using.

Put the two new property values in accumulo-site.xml and restarted cluster.  There was no problem getting the TServers up and running on the 6 TServer cluster.

> I am not a big fan of the move away from the Guava Immutable utils for two reasons.
> 
> * The very clear intent that it was meant to be immutable is lost

I agree. This is one of the things I didn't like about it either. However, the modernizer-maven-plugin catches a lot of these, and unless we believe that plugin to be not worth running at all, they will need to be changed. I think we can try to make some of the intent more clear with inline comments, and possibly utility classes that wrap Java internals.

Regardless of what modernizer-maven-plugin says, there's still value in at least trying to use Java internal stuff, to reduce our use of external libs that could be subject to change between versions. This improves our compatibility/interoperability with other code bases. This change alone won't eliminate the use of Guava, but it could reduce future potential incompatibilities.

> * A lot of the replacement code is sometimes immutable, but not always.

I will have to take a look at the specific cases a bit more closely. This is still a Draft :smiley_cat:

@keith-turner thanks for reviewing this.  I thought I would take a stab at it from a simplistic point of view.  Good comments.  Let me know if you want me to continue with it incorporating the comments or just leave it be for someone else.
I'm looking at this.

I believe the main reason ClientInfo exists is to avoid reconstructing the AuthenticationToken when passing around client properties internally. (Note: ClientInfo and ServerInfo are internal only, and not public API). It'd be great if these could be refactored to consolidate them. I know @mikewalch had spent some time trying to consolidate client properties/info/context a bit already, but I'm not sure which roadblocks he encountered. I look forward to seeing how this turns out.

> I believe the main reason ClientInfo exists is to avoid reconstructing the AuthenticationToken when passing around client properties internally. (Note: ClientInfo and ServerInfo are internal only, and not public API). It'd be great if these could be refactored to consolidate them. I know @mikewalch had spent some time trying to consolidate client properties/info/context a bit already, but I'm not sure which roadblocks he encountered. I look forward to seeing how this turns out.

Yeah I think I am basically continuing what he started.

Since #1204 supersedes this one, we can close this now. The PR will still be available, in case somebody wants to grab the patch from it to backport to 1.9.

@hkeebler it might be worthwhile to make some of these changes like  using `Map.merge` and `Map.computeIfAbsent` to the current code w/o making any other changes.

As far as making this overall class non-blocking, that is up to you.  It may be easier to design a non-blocking pool from the ground up rather than trying to rewrite the existing code.  Could also research existing pooling libraries to see if any are highly concurrent.  I had also thought about using Guava cache in the past, but it was not a good fit because the cache is aMap and conceptually this pool is a multi-map.

Although this is closed (superseded with 2.0 version) testing this would still be valid (esp. if you're set-up).

One condition that I really wanted to verify is that the blocking is happening correctly at the correct "start-up phase". I believe that the blocking is set to before the operations that perform table assignment and wal recovery, but the are threads that have been started and wanted to verify that they are not attempting work that really should also be blocked. 

Two validate this I intended to (using your 6 servers as an example):

1) Set required servers to 8 and a wait time of say 5 minutes - validate that master start up blocks and that no other activity that is assigning tablets occurs) until the time is reached.

2) If time allowed, kill a few servers, set the threshold to 6.  start master, confirm blocking and no other assignments are occurring and then start the remaining servers and see that start-up then continues without issues.

Additional testing would help those that wish to back-port this to 1.9.x versions.
@keith-turner Any interest in investigating this before we start voting on 2.0.0 release candidates?

It would be good to have a reference list (web page) or something for contributors that contains improvements like this ticket for anyone to consider as they are modifying existing code.  It would likely reduce the number of comment iterations back and forth if there was something to reference when updating (or creating new) code, like 1. What can be changed to a forEach, 2. what can use a method reference, etc.
commit includes suggested changes and java 11 testing, includes some standalone testing.

> It would be good to have a reference list (web page) or something for contributors that contains improvements like this ticket for anyone to consider as they are modifying existing code. It would likely reduce the number of comment iterations back and forth if there was something to reference when updating (or creating new) code, like 1. What can be changed to a forEach, 2. what can use a method reference, etc.

Such a page could easily just become a tutorial on the Java language improvements themselves, as new Java versions are released with newer features. Many such pages already exist:

* https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/language/enhancements.html#javase7
* https://www.journaldev.com/2389/java-8-features-with-examples
* https://www.azul.com/90-new-features-and-apis-in-jdk-11/

I don't think it should be a goal to reduce comment iterations. I think it's how we (community members) learn things from each other, like new language features (since we can't always keep up with tech changes on our own).

Aside from the language features that are updated and documented elsewhere on the web, what specific added value do you think such a page would have if we were to maintain a page like that ourselves?
I forget this is an open source project.  Thank you.

I think the value of the page would be to let contributors know what our code standards are.  The code review of pull requests ultimately  enforces code standards anyways.  For example, you and others   remind me about the stream API when I check in iterative code so the present system of enforcing code standards does work.

@milleruntime When you say it is fixed in 2.0.0-SNAPSHOT, do you mean that it is fixed when `Build-Jdk` is 11 and runtime JVM is 8?

If this can be done with low-risk and a small amount of code, it could be backported to 2.0.x or even 1.9.x; but without trying, it's hard to know for sure.

I think the basic design would be something like:

1. Have ZooCache keep references to any Watchers,
2. ZooCache implements a method to match any watchers against some predicate and delete them,
3. In the Master, when a table is deleted, it triggers deletion of any watchers matching paths to that table's location in ZK, and
4. In the TServers, trigger deletion of any watchers for tables that don't match any loaded tablets, whenever a tablet is unloaded or periodically.

> @milleruntime When you say it is fixed in 2.0.0-SNAPSHOT, do you mean that it is fixed when `Build-Jdk` is 11 and runtime JVM is 8?

Yes

> > @milleruntime When you say it is fixed in 2.0.0-SNAPSHOT, do you mean that it is fixed when `Build-Jdk` is 11 and runtime JVM is 8?
> 
> Yes

Weird. Unless I'm misunderstanding something (entirely possible), then Java 11 may have produced different byte code with, and without, the `-release 8` option, even though `-source 1.8` and `-target 1.8` were specified and the animal-sniffer enforcer rule verified the compilation results against Java 1.8. That's very strange, but if it works with the `-release 8` option (which is now automatically added by a profile which is activated when building with javac 9 and later), then I guess all is well.

This could be due to the monitor updates I did for Java 11 to deal with the missing javax/EE stuff, so the monitor worked in Java 11 better. Hopefully the fix is just as simple as it was before. @jzgithub1 you fixed this in #1028 ; want to attempt it again?

Most of what we have that could be called coding standards, are enforced with automation in the build with maven plugins. Most of the rest are "suggestions", "tips", "learned best practices" or even "subjective personal preferences". Deliberation and consensus are more important here than any sort of official coding standards (which change over time).

I'm not opposed to a web page. I just don't know what we'd put on it, and there is some risk of too much documentation (creating haystacks in which to place our needles).
Sure thing.  I will get on it now.

@DonResnik thanks for the PR.  I will take a look at this and give it a test today.

So far I have found two common "types" that are not being removed.
a) Files in a bulk import directory - this may be from a failed ingest, but the failure would have had to of occurred after the files were moved / renamed - they have the expected directory structure and file naming convention.   Because of the age of the files, I need to find more recent occurrences where information for the import would be available in the logs to help determine what may have occurred with the ingest.
b) Files that seem to be from a failed / interrupted compaction - the files are the .tmp_rf files that are used during the compaction process.  There were no running compactions, and running a compaction over the range of the file completed.  It did not appear that this was enough to trigger the file being gc'ed (but I may have been impatient with the check and need to resist if the file has since been removed) However, the file "should" have been removed long before I took any action.

The may be a few other files that don't fit these criteria, and more checking is required to see if there are recent occurrences with tserver and master log files available for the times of the file creation to narrow the scope.

> Can you revert and re-apply as a squash in the future? Running into this pain now :)

I could not think of anything besides force push achieved my goal of making history cleaner, so I decided to just leave it.

I cannot speak directly to the performance test - but in the past, I seem to recall deleting a table while it was splitting (or compacting) could take a long time - I believe that there were changes to improve the time spent for the deletion to occur (I think it may have been related to issues where the delete would block, waiting for the operations to complete - which, being it was to be deleted didn't really matter if it finished or not)  Could it be that these "performance" tests were to validate those solutions?  Maybe this would help guide where / when these tests are run and signal their intention?  

Not saying that the change to remove the annotation is incorrect, just asking more questions.

I suppose revert and re-apply with good commit messages explaining what happened could make history cleaner.  But the extra commits seems to add noise, not sure which is best.

@keith-turner I made most of your recommended changes and put all the synch blocks back in so maybe overkill right now.  Also updated one of the IT tests .

This isn't a bug. This is the intended design. The original garbage collector used to crawl all of HDFS, look for referenced files, and delete everything unreferenced. This was unsafe in the case of failure (some files were too aggressively deleted prior to a reference being added), and a big burden on the name node.

The new garbage collector tries to only delete things that have been explicitly identified as a candidate for deletion, and are provably safe to delete. It errs on the side of leaving things behind, rather than deleting them. Of course, this means that system administrators need to watch their clouds, especially in the case of failures, for anything left behind unreferenced, but that is an intentional trade-off.

Understood - I didn't realize this was intended - I'm working on tooling that would help in identifying these "unreferenced" candidates - we can discuss the best mechanism that would make the utility available to the wider community if that is desired.
Thanks, @elinaawise ; I added a commit to address Ivan's last comment, and also to fix some of the generics warnings, and will merge this in.

Yes, definitely, anything in the category of "update security because of something that happened in Accumulo" (like deleting a table) should be put in one place. Implementers can initiate multiple actions as a result of the call, but the API for the module should only reflect one call.

After a few minutes of my own investigation, I noticed that the original fix in #1028  did not fix the problem. It mistakenly changed the variable from `time` to `runtime` (presumably on the belief that the underlying POJO being presented in the REST interface was the class `RecoveryStatusInformation`, but it was actually `TabletServerRecoveryInformation`).

The actual error was that the `time` field was being interpreted as an absolute time to be used with `new Date(time)`, when the `time` field was actually a time duration, and needed to be displayed as such.
